bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to William Robertson, July 15, 1727

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to William Robertson, clerk of the Council, July 15, 1727, directing him to send the militia commissions for Brunswick and Northumberland counties. He reports news of the raising of the siege of Gibralter, and the arrival of a slave ship. He asks for information about a minister named Thomas Bayley from North Carolina who has applied for a post in Northumberland County, but Carter has been alerted that he is the Bayley who was forced to leave Virginia several years earlier because of misconduct.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to William Robertson, July 15, 1727

opener.dateline:
[Corotoman, Lancaster County, Virginia]
July the 15th. 1727
Mr: Wm: Robertson

div1.p:
Having this Opportunity by the Doctor
think it not amiss to put you in mind of the Military Commissn.
Colonel Harrison gave you directions about for Brunswick
Which you were to Send to me with the Public Papers he gave
you the names of the men he appointed for Captains and desird
Blanks for the Subal-Ternnes.

In Northumberland county in the uper parts
the name of the Canton I do not at Present call to mind there is a
Captain of a foot company Dead and I want blank Commis:
to put another in his room I desire you will take care that this
Commissions are Sent me, It is but dry work however Mr. Crew
desired the Office If he be out of the way or declines the work Mr.
Frances must do it,

Wee have the news of the Seige of Gibralter
being raised brought by Dr. McKensys Sloop from Barbadoes wch:
to be Sure you have more at large. on Sunday night last Arrivd
a Negroe Ship to Colonel Tayloe with one hundred and Thirty odd
Slaves.

A Clergy man named Thomas Bayley came
to me this week for a reccommendation to a parsh in Northumd.
he is gone to apply himself to the Vestry he came from North Carolina
hath his wife with him he hath left his orders behind hime other
wise had gon near to have Surprized me into a Letter talking
with Dr. Nicholas Yesterday about him very-ly beleive tis the Bayley
that Colonel Drysdale Sent out of the Governmt. for his gross misde=
meanors when you write this way I desire you will Send a detail
of the Crimes he was charged with he brought me a paper of long
Inconiums with abundance of Subscriptions and had the Cunning to
personate a very meek humble behaviour

Mr. Hickman is very dilatory with his probatted
Administrations I wish I had them to sign at my Leizure I am

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter letter book, 1727 May-1728 July, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.
The name of Carter's home, the county, and colony have been added for clarity to this unheaded draft.
[1] Carter refers to his son-in-law, Dr. George Nicholas, who was traveling to Williamsburg where Robertson lived.

[2] John Tayloe (1687-1747) of Mt. Airy, Richmond County, who served as justice, burgess, colonel of militia, and as a member of the Council after 1732. (Ryland. Richmond County Virginia. . . . pp. 115-16.)

[3] Thomas Baylie (Bayley, Bailey, b. 1683?) was one of the most notorious colonial Virginia clergymen.Commissary Blair had written to the bishop of London in 1724, "We have at present two Ministers (Mr. Thomas Baylie and . . . ) so very scandalous for drunkenness and fighting and Quarreling in their drink that many grevious complaints are brought to me against them, and indeed the Country rings of the scandal given by them." Baylie was the minister at that time of Newport Parish, Isle of Wight County. The parish determined to get rid of Baylie, and in 1725, brought an agreement to the Governor and Council by which Baylie agreed to relinquish his ministry and leave the colony; he disputed the amount of salary he was to receive and was awarded the full year. (John K. Nelson. A Blessed Company: Parishes, Parsons, and Parishoners in Anglican Virginia, 1690-1776. [Chapel Hill and London: University of North Carolina Press, 2001]. pp. 153, 304, 401; and, McIlwaine. Executive Journals of the Council. . . ., 4[1721-1739]:89-90. )

[4] After Governor Hugh Drysdale's death, the Council appointed Richard Hickman to manage the Governor's house and its gardens. His name appears a number of times in the Council minutes as he took out land patents. From Carter's referecne in this letter complaining that "Mr. Hickman is very dilatory with his probatted Administrations," it seems that Hickman must have done some other work for the colonial government. (McIlwaine. Executive Journals of the Council. . . ., 4[1721-1739]:114. )
